messages: Enjoy the beauty of science? Behold the new scientific imagery at the Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Center's public galleries. Scientific art lights up Main Street Art and science converge in the public galleries at MIT's Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research.
Science = art. Explore the online gallery of the MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer: http://mitsha.re/YaiT3 #SciArt Timeline Photos

“If you just focus on what you know, you’re blinding yourself to new opportunities.” Tyler Jacks, professor in the MIT Department of Biology and head of the David H. Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research, is the recipient of the 2016 Killian Award. Targeting cancer from many angles Killian Award recipient Tyler Jacks fosters interdisciplinary, innovative cancer research.

Congratulations to Tyler Jacks, director of the MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research and professor in the MIT Department of Biology, for being named this year's Killian Award winner! Tyler Jacks receives MIT’s Killian Award Cancer biologist and Koch Institute director recognized with MIT faculty’s top honor.

“We have presented results showing that the spleen is the main organ that defines the shape of the circulating red blood cells,” says Ming Dao, a principal research scientist in MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE). How the spleen filters blood Computer model finds slits in the spleen impose a “physical fitness test” on red blood cells.

It's the Monday after Commencement, so that means the MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) has updated its bulletin board! 

Photo: Maia Weinstock/MIT Timeline Photos

New research from the MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) paves the way for rechargeable batteries with almost indefinite lifetimes: http://mitsha.re/R03QP

Image: Yan Wang Going solid-state could make batteries safer and longer-lasting New research paves the way for rechargeable batteries with almost indefinite lifetimes, researchers say.
The magic of glass and metal: The MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) has just reopened its shiny new glass lab, forge, and foundry! MIT Glass Lab, Forge, and Foundry

Medallions of the MIT seal from the MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) foundry. Watch how they're made in this brief video: http://mitne.ws/1C8LTgg

DMSE is home to students who are builders and creators. They strive to understand the how and why of materials and apply them to change our world. Hands-on education is valuable, so students and instructors, often immersed in a high-tech world, treasure the tactile experience of melting, annealing, cooling, hammering, and bending. Learn more: http://dmse.mit.edu/

MIT graduates follow many career paths. MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) grad Ayr Muir '00, SM '01 went on to found Clover Food Lab, a thriving vegetarian restaurant business.  Clover Food Lab’s secret ingredient? Data. Lots of it. - The Boston Globe How the Cambridge vegetarian fast-food phenom went from one truck to six—plus five restaurants, a deal with Whole Foods, and an imminent expansion to D.C.

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT One of the strongest lightweight materials known

Researchers in MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering are seeking to redesign concrete — the most widely used human-made material in the world — by following nature’s blueprints. Finding a new formula for concrete Researchers look to bones and shells as blueprints for stronger, more durable concrete.

A new model of sediment flow in coastal vegetation developed by researchers from the MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering could restore marine plant life: http://mitne.ws/1FkvC4a Predicting sediment flow in coastal vegetation Model could help engineers design erosion-prevention strategies in marshes, wetlands, aquatic forests.
For World Water Day, watch "Research for a Thirsty World," a new video from students in the MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering: http://mitsha.re/1Om6qTk Timeline Photos

MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering Professor Dara Entekhabi discusses NASA's mission to study how soil, water, and carbon interact. Full story: http://newsoffice.mit.edu/2015/3-questions-dara-entekhabi-nasa-smap-satellite-0126

Image courtesy of NASA 3 Questions: Dara Entekhabi on NASA’s soil-moisture mission MIT professor is lead scientist on three-year mission to study how soil, water, and carbon interact.

Researchers in the MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering have found that collagen can produce forces 300 times stronger than those generated by muscles: http://t.co/8zOEB2JJVg

Image courtesy of the researchers New analysis explains collagen’s force Experiments and simulations show that adding or removing water makes the material push and pull.

How does #Ebola spread? Lydia Bourouiba of the MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering explains what we know. 3 Questions: Lydia Bourouiba on Ebola virus transmission Research on disease transmission through aerosol droplets raises questions about Ebola’s spread.

Theresa Oehmke, an senior in the MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, travels the globe in pursuit of her interests at the boundaries between water and land. Her story: http://mitne.ws/1HFSHU1

A surprising discovery from the MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering and the Weizmann Institute of Science: Corals are not passive as once believed; rather, they are active engineers of their own environment. http://mitne.ws/1w2MY3C

MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering Congratulations to the MIT Steel Bridge team for winning first place in economy and second place overall at the national competition held May 31-June 1 at the University of Washington in Seattle. (L to R) Alexis Ludena, Leonidia Garbis, Pierre Ghisbain, Alex McCarthy, Maria Tou, Grant Iwamoto, Nicky Soane, Sharone Small, Dagin Faulkner, and Matt Pires.

A new study by researchers in the MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering shifts the focus to the first few days of an epidemic, determining how likely the 40 largest U.S. airports are to influence the spread of a contagious disease originating in their home cities. New model of disease contagion ranks U.S. airports in terms of their spreading influence - MIT News. Airports in New York, Los Angeles and Honolulu are judged likeliest to play a significant role in the growth of a pandemic.

The MIT School of Architecture + Planning has launched a new entrepreneurship accelerator, DesignX, to cultivate and assist students and faculty developing products, systems, and companies that focus on design and the built environment. Entrepreneurship by design New DesignX accelerator speeds innovation at the School of Architecture and Planning.

Interplanetary architecture: Students and faculty in the MIT School of Architecture + Planning are designing habitats for #Mars. Interplanetary architecture Faculty and students grapple with 3-D printing a habitable structure on Mars.

Lesson in perspective from the MIT School of Architecture + Planning.

"Unblocked," a project by architecture students Evelyn Ting and Shiyu Wei, is "a prototype for a new kind of pop-up exhibition space. Made from mylar, it is a lightweight system that can be pre-cut to specific geometries and stitched together offsite, and expanded and assembled onsite." U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry said in an address at MIT that the effort to limit climate change was a dire “race against time,” but one that could be successful due to the economic promise of renewable energy. John Kerry: Climate drive an urgent “race against time” At MIT, U.S. Secretary of State highlights peril of climate change, economic promise of clean energy.

The student-led group Fossil Free MIT and the MIT administration have reached an agreement on MIT climate action that brings to an end the group’s months-long sit-in. Agreement on climate-related action reached by MIT administration and student-led group Four-part plan signals effort to build on last year’s climate action plan, and an end to months-long protest.

Ideas wanted! The MIT Climate CoLab has opened 10 contests seeking climate change solutions. What's your idea? MIT lab opens 10 contests on climate change Proposals submitted will help crowdsource the makings of national and global climate action plans.

History in the making! In light of this weekend's international agreement to curb fossil fuel emissions, the MIT Energy Initiative highlights MIT research and strategies shared at the #COP21 climate talks. Sharing climate research and strategies in Paris MIT events throughout climate talks underscore Institute’s global perspectives and partnerships.

MIT Energy Initiative report from #COP21: How MIT and Climate Interactive are bringing empathy to the UN climate talks with a negotiation role-play. The MIT community is beginning the process of healing from the recent tragic events on campus and around the Boston area. At this time, the Institute is working on plans to remember Patrol Officer Sean Collier; details will be announced as they become available. MIT community members who seek resources in dealing with this tragedy should visit http://together.mit.edu/.

In memory of MIT Police Officer Sean Collier, who was killed in the line of duty on Thursday, April 18, 2013. The MIT community remembers Officer Collier: http://mit.edu/newsoffice/2013/obit-officer-sean-collier-0419.html Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s cover photo

MIT Engineering Systems Division professor Yossi Sheffi writes about the growth of logistics hubs and their role in driving economic growth What can logistics do for you? - MIT News Office In a new book, an MIT professor argues that investment in global transportation hubs can spur a ‘feedback loop’ of regional growth.

How is computing changing the architect’s job? Bits of buildings: How is computing changing the architect’s job? - MIT News Office In a new book, an MIT researcher looks at the influence of high-tech simulations on the profession of architecture.

Researchers in the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences have observed a star beating for its eccentric planet. #ScienceValentines 💓 The heart of a far-off star beats for its planet Scientists observe first planet-induced stellar pulsations.

Research from the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences found that certain greenhouse gases can cause sea levels to rise for hundreds of years after the pollutants have been cleared from the atmosphere. Short-lived greenhouse gases cause centuries of sea-level rise Through warming effects, methane and other gases impact rising seas long after leaving the atmosphere.

Researchers from MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences , Princeton University, and elsewhere have developed a new technique to monitor the seasonal changes in Greenland’s ice sheet. Tracking Greenland’s ice melt with seismic waves Technique uses vibrations generated by ocean waves to monitor ice sheet’s seasonal changes.

Is there life beyond the solar system? Three exoplanets co-discovered by scientists in the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences are raising new hopes of finding out. Scientists discover potentially habitable planets Just 40 light years from Earth, planets are best targets so far for search for extraterrestrial life.

Meet Colette Heald, associate professor in the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences and MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering who studies how particles affect air quality and climate. #womeninSTEM Colette Heald: There’s something in the air Chemist studies atmospheric gases and particles, and how they affect air quality and climate.

“We really owe microbes a lot, because there would be no complex life on Earth without these bugs.” –Tanja Bosak, scientist in the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences Microbe sleuth Tanja Bosak examines how life and the Earth evolved in tandem during their early history together.

“This thing missed, but chances are, at this size, we will one day find an object headed for an impact,” says Richard Binzel, a professor of planetary sciences in MIT’s Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences. “Depending on where it’s falling, you might need to know whether it’s going to survive passage through the atmosphere, and how many fragments [will make impact]. For children with speech and language disorders, early-childhood intervention can make a great difference in their later academic and social success. But many such children go undiagnosed until kindergarten or even later.

“The operational scenario that was envisioned for this was a hazmat situation where people are suited up with the full suit, and they go in and explore an environment,” says Maurice Fallon, a research scientist in the MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory. “The current approach would be to textually summarize what they had seen afterward — ‘I went into this room on the left, I saw this, I went into the next room,’ and so on. We want to try to automate that.” Automatic building mapping could help emergency responders - MIT News Office A prototype sensor array that can be worn on the chest automatically maps the wearer’s environment, recognizing movement between floors.

At the IEEE International Symposium on Performance Analysis of Systems and Software earlier this month, researchers from MIT’s Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL) presented a new method for improving the efficiency of hardware simulations of multicore chips. Unlike competing methods, it guarantees that the simulator won’t go into “deadlock” — a state in which cores get stuck waiting for each other to relinquish system resources, such as memory. Simulating tomorrow’s chips - MIT News Office A new system makes hardware models of multicore chips more efficient, easier to design and more reliable.

“We did it again!” For the second time, the LIGO Scientific Collaboration has detected gravitational waves from colliding black holes, further solidifying Albert Einstein's theory of relativity. Full story: http://mitsha.re/7qYU301i1L1

This animation represents the merger of two black holes and the gravitational waves that ripple outward during the event. The black holes — representing those detected by LIGO on Dec. 26, 2015 — were 14 and eight times the mass of the sun until they merged into a single black hole 21 times the sun's mass. One solar mass was converted to gravitational waves. In reality, the area near the black holes would appear highly warped, and the gravitational waves would be difficult to see directly.

Video: LIGO/T. Pyle LIGO again detects gravitational waves

#MIThistory: Why is there a "J" sign on MIT Building 44? In 1974, MIT Professor Samuel C. C. Ting discovered a new kind of heavy elementary particle. Since the last meson was named the K particle, Ting named the new one the J particle. Ting won the 1976 Nobel Prize for this discovery, and gave his acceptance speech in Chinese, the first Nobel laureate to do so.

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/jparticle

“You have all this data, and clearly, if you want to store it, what people would naturally do is compress it,” says Bonnie Berger, a professor in MIT's Department of Mathematics. “The problem is that eventually you have to look at it, so you have to decompress it to look at it. But our insight is that if you compress the data in the right way, then you can do your analysis directly on the compressed data. And that increases the speed while maintaining the accuracy of the analyses.” Searching genomic data faster - MIT News Office Biologists’ capacity for generating genomic data is increasing more rapidly than computing power. A new algorithm will help them keep up.

Every year, more than a million Americans receive an artificial hip or knee prosthesis. Such implants are designed to last many years, but in about 17 percent of patients who receive a total joint replacement, the implant eventually loosens and has to be replaced early, which can cause dangerous complications for elderly patients.

To help minimize these burdensome operations, a team of MIT chemical engineers has developed a new coating for implants that could help them better adhere to the patient’s bone, preventing premature failure.  New coating for hip implants could prevent premature failure - MIT News Office Nanoscale films developed at MIT promote bone growth, creating a stronger seal between implants and patients’ own bone.
